title: Bibliography
publication_title: The Lithographs of James McNeill Whistler: The Digital Edition
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body">Letters and other archival materials used in this catalogue come from four main sources: the Glasgow University Library Special Collections (GUL); the Freer Gallery of Art Archives, Smithsonian Institution (Freer Letterpress, FGA); the Pennell Collection at the Library of Congress (LCPC); and the New York Public Library (NYPL). This material appears with the reference numbers used by those institutions.

Throughout the text, Whistler’s lithographs are referred to by the Chicago numbers established in the present catalogue. References to and illustrations of works of art by Whistler in other media are accompanied by numbers from the appropriate catalogue raisonné: Edward G. Kennedy, The Etched Work of Whistler (San Francisco, 1978) (K); Margaret F. MacDonald, James McNeill Whistler: Drawings, Pastels, and Watercolours. A Catalogue Raisonné (New Haven and London, 1995) (M); and Andrew McLaren Young, Margaret F. MacDonald, Robin Spencer, and Hamish Miles, The Paintings of James McNeill Whistler, 2 vols. (New Haven and London, 1980) (YMSM). In order to clarify the editions being used, two important texts by Whistler are cited as follows: Mr. Whistler’s “Ten O’Clock” (London, 1885) (Ten O’Clock 1885); The Gentle Art of Making Enemies (London and New York, 1892) (Gentle Art 1892).

This part of the bibliography lists, in chronological order, exhibitions held during (and immediately after) Whistler’s lifetime known to have included lithographs by the artist; similarly, reviews have been selected because they refer to those lithographs. Complete information about exhibition titles, venues, and opening and closing dates is provided wherever possible, and the existence or absence of a catalogue is noted. The reader is encouraged to refer to the Selective Chronology of Exhibitions, Publications, and Sales, which provides documentation of the negotiations leading up to the exhibitions, and to the catalogue entries, which include lifetime exhibition histories for individual lithographs where such information is available.

Also arranged chronologically, this part of the bibliography provides full references for the sources cited in abbreviated form (i.e., author’s surname and date of publication) in volumes one and two. Additional sources relating to mid- to late-nineteenth-century lithography in general and to Whistler’s lithographic activity in particular are also included. Citations for sources not included in this list of references may be found in the notes accompanying the catalogue entries and essays.

For books and catalogues published in multiple editions, the earliest edition in general use is cited. In some cases, items cited from clippings and scrapbooks may lack certain bibliographical data. Unless otherwise noted, all nineteenth-century newspapers and periodicals were published in London. For a more comprehensive Whistler bibliography, see Robert H. Getscher and Paul G. Marks, James McNeill Whistler and John Singer Sargent: Two Annotated Bibliographies (New York and London, 1986).
